titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Constitutional Convention of Washington Territory Collection 1878-1978
Constitutional Convention of Washington Territory Collection
titlestmt.author: Elizabeth Hambleton

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2020-03-30.
profiledesc.descrules: Finding aid based on DACS (Describing Archives: A Content Standard), 2nd Edition.

did.unittitle: Constitutional Convention of Washington Territory Collection

origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: Whitman College. Whitman College and Northwest Archives

did.abstract: The Constitutional Convention of Washington Territory Collection, which dates from 1878 through 1978, contains records and documents related to the Constitutional Convention of Washington Territory in the late nineteenth century.

acqinfo.p: Materials found in collection; provenance is unknown.

bioghist.p: The first Washington Territory Constitutional Convention happened in Walla Walla, Washington in the summer of 1878. During this time, legislators came together to draft a state constitution that was approved by the majority of voters. This document was not recognized by congress. The official Washington State Constitution was composed over a decade later in 1889.

scopecontent.p: The Constitutional Convention of Washington Territory Collection, which dates from 1878 through 1978, consists of congressional records, an article from The Washington Historical Quarterly, and the petition to the legislative assembly of Washington Territory concerning giving women the right to vote. There is also a member list for the Walla Walla 1878 Constitutional Convention, a letter to Professor Vernon Carstensen at the University of Washington in 1978, and a xerox of a journal from the Constitutional Convention of 1878.
